text:
Yum!  This was my first attempt at making gauc and I was not let down by the high rating on this recipe.  I adapted it a little to my taste by adding more cilantro and garlic and adding some ground cumin.  When choosing your avocados choose ones that are blemish free and have a slight give when squeezed lightly.  There are so many different varities that color is not a good indication.  Sure this has a lot of fat in it, but it's the good fat that our bodies need to keep are skin supple and our joints lubricated (tell that to my hips!)!

07/07/08 Update
I just had to update my review on this recipe.  My first review was the first time that I had made this recipe - now I am known for my guac!  I don't use a recipe any more, but it is similiar to this.  I think the key to delicious guac is lots of garlic and a lot of lime juice.  The lime juice does more than flavor the quac - it keeps it from turning brown.  I also add jalepenios (sp?) seeded, ribbed and finely chopped for a little heat.  Another thing I add is some cumin - one of my favorite spices.  Teh quac I make is chunky, but chunky from the tomatoes, onion and peppers - the avocado I make very smooth.  You don't want to make this too soon as some discoloration can occur.  I have made it the night before and it's fine but I prefer to make it a few hours before hand.  That way it stays nice and fresh but the flavors have time to marry.  Regardless of when you make it always flatten the top surface smooth and squirt the jui

text:
This was excellent!!  When I can find ripe avacados at Costco, I buy them because they come 5 to a package and that's cheaper than buying them individually.  I scaled the recipe down (using only 1 avacado) because it was just me eating this. Instead of chopping up the onions and garlic, I used onion and garlic powder.  In my opinion, they taste just as good and are much quicker.   I also added a spoonful of salsa to mine.  I love eating this alone with chips or as a side dish to my lunch or dinner.  Thanks for sharing.  Will definitley make again!!

text:
Great Guacamole! This was everything guacamole should be: smooth and creamy with just the right amount of flavor. Nothing overpowering, nothing artificial, no jarred salas or other oddities to make it some sort of "creation". I de-seeded the tomatoes, used red onion and added a little more than 1/4 tsp. of cumin - it went great with warm tortilla chips! This recipe is a definite keeper for sure!!!

text:
Awesome taste!  It took me longer than 10 minutes to prepare, but it might be that I am just slow at chopping and cutting.  Also, be wary of over mashing the avacado - I thought I didn't like it chunky, but smooth becomes kinda soupy.  With the whole lime, this doesn't turn brown for over 24 hours in a sealed container.  Best to eat immediately (or after chilled for an hour), lots of liquid pools in it after a couple days. UPDATE:  Do not freeze this to use at a later time ... the consistency is just strange after thawing and the flavors change.  Still the best Guac, though. :)

Thank you for a great addition! :D

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Delicious. NOTES: *I leave out the tomatoes and serve pico de gallo alongside. On the rare occasion there are leftovers, mixed-in tomato makes the guacamole go off faster. Same amount of work, just throw the tomatoes in a separate bowl and toss some extra onion, chili, cilantro, and lime. *Lime acts like salt on the palate, so add salt after the lime juice; you will end up using less. *I always add some ground toasted cumin seed and a seeded jalapeno. *Great with and without garlic. *Reserve half the avocado chunks to add at the end for textural variety. *The most important thing, though, is to use ripe avocados. Buy them a day or 2 beforehand, then let them sit in a brown paper bag on the counter with a ripe apple, pear, or bananas until the avocados are softer. *If the avocados aren't perfectly delicious, I add a little extra virgin olive oil to the mix.

text:
Excellent! My husband loved it! Fresh Cilantro is a must(.70 cents a bunch). We like chunkier style Guacamole so mashed two of the avocados & chopped the third into very small pieces. These pieces will mush up alittle as you stir in other ingredients, but still give it alittle chunk. If it is still too chunky you can mash it alittle with back of spatula. I will use this recipe on a regular basis. Thanks!

text:
The "best" guacamole being purely subjective, in my book this comes pretty darn close. I added a finely chopped jalapeno pepper, 1/2 tsp. cumin and salt to taste rather than measuring out a teaspoon.  I removed the seeds and pulp from the tomato to make sure I wouldn't end up with it making the guacamole watery and just as a matter of personal preference I cut back on the cilantro, a taste for which we are slowly acquiring.

text:
This absolutely ROCKS!  I have been making various forms of guacamole since I was a youngster in Texas, and I have never found one with so much robust flavor and kick.  Follow the recipe!  You won't be disappointed.  I think one of the keys is mashing the avacados with the salt and lime prior to the other ingredients.  It helps to meld the flavors, and prevents the the guacamole from going brown.  The cayenne adds a nice kick with just a pinch, so use with discretion.  The only thing I will mention is that I used sweet vidalia onions which are readily available this time of year on the east coast.  Other onions might make it too "oniony."  Thanks for a great recipe!  I'll be using this one many times to come!

I used to work at a Mexican resturant where I had to make gaucamole at guests table (cheezy, i know)..... People would tell me that they drove 25 min out of their way ect ect..... just for the gaucamoli.  The recipe is almost the same, except we'd use 2 avocados, RED onion (not yellow- yuk), and diced jalepenos.  We didn't use garlic or pepper, but they sound like good additions.  Can't forget the jalepenos!

I personally like mine with a little extra veggies.  yum!

Display Name:
Jessica

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has become "my guacamole recipe" which I've been using for about 3 years. Shhh, cause I don't tell people! Seriously, I make it for EVERY single party and bbq I host, and most I attend. Each time, people say "wow, you make amazing quacamole." If they only knew how simple it is. The only advice I have is:
1. People tend to like it more when the avocado is a bit chunkier, so don't over mash.
2. You can't use too much lime juice. Seriously. Keep adding more till it tastes perfect.
3. Ripen those avocados in a brown paper bag  off-season. They'll taste a bit more summery that way.

Wow - Wow - WOW!  This is one of the best recipes I have ever made.  I've never really like gaucamole but this sounded so interesting I had to try it!  I took the advice of other reviewers and used alot of lime juice - 3 small limes to be precise - tons of garlic, probably about 3 heaping teaspoons and I did 4 avocados.  I put an overflowing tablespoon of chopped fresh cilantro in and  I used canned diced tomatoes because I forgot to buy fresh and it was ultimate perfection.  My mother in law who is the pickiest eater and my sister in law who has food allergies couldn't stay away from it.  It was amazing!

This guacamole was quite good but I did wish I hadn't added an extra ingredient which was CUMIN. If you don't want to eat anything that smells like BODY ODOR than I advise you to NOT USE CUMIN. text:
This guacamole was delicious- better than many restaurants!  I made it for a football party and it got rave reviews from everyone.  

I made a couple of changes.  First, I used 5 avocados.  I mashed up 3 of them and diced the other two for a more texture.  I used red onion, and I only used about 1/3 cup.  I added more cayenne than called for, and next time I am going to add jalapeno for some added kick.  This is my new guacamole recipe.  Thank you!

country:
None
text:
I've made this several times.  It is by far the best guacamole recipe I've tried.  To keep from turning brown too quickly, I make sure to use enough lime AND lemon juice.  After preparing the guacamole, I place the pits in the bowl w/ the dip.  I press plastic wrap (side that has contact w/ dip rubbed w/ lemon juice) against the dip surface, removing any air pockets.  You will be amazed at how long it will stay looking a fresh, vibrant green.

text:
this was my first time making guacamole and I think it came out delicious! However, I don't think it tasted like guacamole, but rather another type of dip. Unfortunately, one of my avocados was rotten, so I had to scale down the recipe for 2. In doing so, the lime and garlic became overwhelming. I did add cayenne and cumin, and what resulted was pretty good, just a little heavy in onion and lime, but maybe I didn't dice the onion small enough.
ETA: I've made this many times. I add a little more tomato than it calls for, plus cayenne and cumin, and it is so delicious!

text:
I couldn't decide between this recipe and another on this site that appeared to be much spicier, so I made both.  Both turned out very well and I'm giving five stars to each, but they were very different dips.  This one was like something you'd get at a restaurant or packaged from a store.  Very green, nice flavor, mildly spicy.  The other recipe resulted a very different appearance and much hotter dip.  I like spicy, so the other is my favorite, but this is an excellent dip that most people will prefer.

userID:
1037986
Display Name:
OkinawanPrincess
isPro:

followersCount:
220

madeRecipesCount:

favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/661917.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used three ripe Haas Avocados. I mashed up two and cut up one since I like my guacamole chunkier. I seeded and rough chopped 2 large roma tomatoes. I also like my guacamole with chunks of tomatoes. I used one red onion and I added a pinch of cumin and Hawaiian sea salt for seasoning. I also snuck in a half of jalapeno, seeded, ribbed and finely chopped. The fresh cilantro and lime juice is what gives this nice rounded flavor. I thought this was delicious and comes fairly close to what I grew up eating. The guacamole was smooth, creamy, with just the right amount of flavor. This was fresh tasting, nothing overpowering or too spicy, just the way I like it!

Then I added a pinch of homemade taco seasoning instead of cayenne.  It received rave reviews and was all gone before I had more than a bite.  Definitely a great recipe.

I made this exactly as written and it is very good guacamole. Will definitely make again in the future. Like all guacamole I had problems with it going brown after a bit and someone told me if you place one of the pits from one of the avocado in the center of the dip it will keep it from going brown.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Take 2 - MUCH BETTER!

OK the first time I did this, I threw the onion, tomato, cilantro & garlic in the food processor - BIG MISTAKE! Do NOT do this!  It was horrible guacamole!  It was more salsa than guacamole!

So the 2nd time I made it I used around 1/2 cup of onion that I chopped myself, and 2 small tomatoes that I chopped myself.  Mixed together with minced garlic & Cilantro & set aside.  I then mashed up the 3 Avocados, and chopped up 1/2 of one so it was nice and chunky.  Added in the onion/tomato mixture with the Lime Juice.  PERFECTION!

Oh and to keep from browning - we've learned that leaving the seed of 1 avocado pressed into the top of the guacamole & then covering it somehow keeps it from browning! Not sure why but whatever works!! Try this recipe, you won't be disappointed - just don't throw it in the food processor!

Thanks for sharing - I will make from here on out!!

Best guac EVER! Had some chips leftover from mexican dinner last night and had nothing to put on them, so decided to make this. Used 1/2 can diced tomatoes, 3 tbs dried minced onion, and 1 1/2 tbsp dried cilantro since those were what i had on hand. Also added a few chopped pickled jalapenos--we like spicy! Didn't wait an hr. before tasting and it's already excellent!! Can't wait to eat more later after it's gotten a chance to sit a little while.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome. We are big guacamole fans and I se no need to ever have or try another recipe. This is a great base recipe that can easily be adjusted to suit your preferences. Perfecto! Made three batches in one week for various gatherings and it was a hit at all of them. We are big on bold flavor so I made the following changes: increased lime to 1.5, tripled diced garlic, used 1/2 tsp. freshly ground red chili peppers instead of ground cayenne, eliminated cilantro, added 1 tsp. garlic powder, added 1/2 tsp. onion powder, added 1/2 tsp. ground cumin. Delicioso!!

I've always made my guacamole this way.  The only thing that I do differently is omit the cayenne and add one very small seeded and finely diced jalapeno (it's not as hot as you might think, but you can reduce the amount added to suit your taste).

Delicious!  Left out the cayenne because I didn't have any and it was still fabulous!

Edit 06/25/2008: I have made this guacamole at least 4 times for various parties and it is always the first thing gone.  I usually dice up the veggies up to a day early and let them marinate with the cilantro, spices, and lime juice.  I just add and mash the avocado right before serving.  I LOVE this recipe!

text:
I can't help but review this recipe - because I'm a bit amazed by the reveiws that I have read.

On the one hand - I agree - this IS guacamole.  Certain things can only be made one way - and this is it.  If you want to add a bunch of other  junk - have at it - but call it soemthing else because it's not guacamole.

On the other hand - I'm a bit amazed at how people are fawning over this recipe - essentially for the same reason.  It is just a basic - proper - guacamole recipe.  Some things are best simple and traditional - IMHO - this is one!

In the end - I'll say - if this isn't how you make guacamole - then you are in for treat.

I have been making this guac for about 5 years now and I get rave reviews from everyone. Make sure you have enough salt and lime in it to make it taste real good. Sometimes I make it chunkier by not mashing the avocado but cutting it into chunks and adding diced tomato and onion, along with the rest of the ingredients. That makes sort of an avocado salsa. Mashed or diced- it is Deelicious! Also, I never put cayenne pepper in it before- I will have to try that!

text:
I make fresh guacamole a lot, but this is the first time I've put lime juice in. I didn't use all the juice of one lime because it seemed like a lot and it was. I used about 1/2 to 3/4 of the juice from 1 lime and it was overpowering. The recipe needs to say how much lime juice instead of the juice of 1 lime since lime size can vary. I'm assuming you only need a tablespoon or so.

text:
Good recipe. The lime juice helps keep the avocado from turning brown, so does leaving the pit in the mixture. But, the best way is to lay a piece of plastic wrap directly on the guacamole until serving time. It's the air that turns it brown. I do all three and never have it turn brown. Of course, it's usually gone before it has a chance=)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is pretty much how I have been making my guacamole for years, however, I use lemon juice instead of lime and a dash or two of Tabasco sauce rather than cayenne. I prefer not to add the tomatoes to the guacamole as if you have leftovers, they tend to get everything soggy. I like to serve guacamole and chips alongside my salsa and I would never add sour cream to the guac. as another person suggested. Imo, it takes away from the flavor of the avocados. For the best guacamole, use California Hass avocados.

text:
The only reason you would need to use limes in this recipe is to keep the guacamole from turning brown.  I was not a big fan of the lime flavor in the guacamole.  If you are going to serve the guacamole right away you do not need to use the limes.  The key to making the guacamole is to use ripe avacados.  When choosing avacados they cannot be too hard or too soft.

I marinated chicken breasts for 2 hours in fresh lemon juice, cumin, chopped cilantro and kosher salt with fresh ground pepper. text:
I use this ALL the time.  I work one saturday a month and we always have a potluck and all my co-workers always ask for this guac!  To avoid browning (since I make my guac the night before I take it to work) I take an extra lime and squeeze all the juice out over the guac.  When I open the tupperware the next day I just mix the extra lime juice in (I prefer mine w/the extra lime, you could just pour it out if you wanted to) and serve!  Very, very good...and you can never add enough garlic!  Enjoy!

We loved this recipe..The only change I made was used key lime juice (fresh limes were floating in our Corona's) and I added a little salsa.  I mashed my avocados with my potato masher and diced my tomatoes and onion very small...Do not leave Out the Cilantro...So good!  Can't tell you if this is good the next day..didn't last that long...Thanks for a great recipe!

If you're wondering if you chop the stems of the cilantro...you do not. Use the leaves. This recipe is fabulous. You can also swap lemon for lime but don't use a huge lemon and don't use as much lemon juice as you would lime. Lime is a little sweeter than lemon.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fantastic!  I made it for the Sunday football game, and it was so good I had the leftovers for breakfast.  AND LUNCH!  Wow -- it tastes even better the next day.  I have two tips:  1) If you think you'll have leftovers, safe the avocado pits and store them in the same container with the leftovers -- that will keep it from discoloring & turning black.  2) If you want your guacamole super-chunky, blend & mix all the other ingredients first, then add the chopped avocados last.  That way they will hold their shape better.

text:
This recipie was a bit salty and had waaaay to much of a bad garlic after taste on your breath.  So the second time i made this  i added 1 more avacado , 1/4 teaspoon of fresh garlic, and a very small can  of Golden Sweet Corn.  Chili's resturant now serves Corn Guacamole.....thats where i got the idea! If i didnt add these things then, for me personally, the overall taste of the guacamole would have been too garlic and salty tasting.

text:
AWESOME. This rocked. The only tweaks were..I used 1 TBSP of lime juice, 1 TBSP of lemon juice. The onion was a red onion and I used 2 tsps of minced garlic because I'm a garlic lover. I used 1/2 can of petite diced tomatoes w/jalapeno's drained as the tomato part. The consistancy was perfect. Just a tip to keep the avocado from turning brown, once you put it in the container for storage, take wax or plastic wrap and place directly on the dip to remove as much air as possible then cover with the lid.

text:
This was my first attempt at making Guacamole and it was perfect.  Only change I made was to cut the salt to 1/2 tsp.  I probably used about 1/8 tsp of cayenne pepper.  
As others suggested, keeping the pit in with the dip prevents the avocado (and your dip) from turning brown.
I'll be making this again!

EASY and addictively good!!! best guacamole ive ever had... i used only two avocados(mashed with my whisk) and all the ingredients int he recipe but i didnt measure, i just eyeballed. i also used red onion and threw in some cumin and cayenne. woukldnt change a thing . served with whole grain tortilla chips,  healthy and tasty

**update, i forgot the garlic once and didnt miss it. ALSO its very important to season your avocado 1st w the salt, cumin, paprika, and lemon juice then add in everythign else.

text:
We changed this recipe a bit by substituting the lime juice with lemon juice and doubling the salt, onion and tomatoes. Also, we left out the cayenne pepper and cilantro. We folded in 1/2 c. sour cream to make it smooth and creamy. It makes your avocados go further, too. This is a family favorite at our holiday gatherings. We serve it with tortilla chips and Fritos.

All I can say is WOW.  I made a 3 serving version with 2 avocados (topped 4 fajitas with some to spare).  I served this on top of Paula Dean's Gold Medal Sizzling Fajitas.  Use a fork to mash the guacamole.  Putting the pit into the guacamole keeps it from oxidizing...the lime juice helps with that too.  YUM!!!

country:
None
text:
This is the first time I've made guacamole.  I have always liked it, but my husband not so much.  I doubled the recipe and used the following ratios: 6 Avacados, 1 lime, 2 tsp salt, 1/2 onion chopped, 4 small tomatos, 1/3 bunch chopped cilantro, 2 cloves garlic.  I would have liked to use a whole onion, but my husband doesn't like onion so much.  He loved this guacamole and had me make two batchs in a week.  The first batch, I used 2 limes and it was too much.  1 lime in the 2nd batch was perfect.  This will be a regular for us.

Wow, the proportions on this are perfect. This is easily the best guacamole I've ever tasted (and let me tell you, I've tried quite a few)! The best way to get this just right is to use really fresh ingredients. If the avocado is just a little bit tough, it'll prevent the guacamole from coming out too liquid-y and will taste that much better :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never liked guacamole, but I needed some for seven layer dip.  After making this, I forced myself to taste it.  Oh wow was it delicious.  I was so excited about this recipe.  But after it sat in the refrigerator for a couple of hours, it seemed very salty.  I will definitely try it again, but with half the salt and maybe a little less lime (my lime was very juicy).
*(Update)* I made this again with a little more avocado (my avocados were larger than the first time a made it) and I used only  tsp salt but still plenty of lime juice.  It wasn't as good immediately, but after an hour in the refrigerator for the flavors to meld, it was delicious.  So I suppose if I plan to eat it immediately without time for the flavors to meld I would add almost a tsp of salt.  But usually I make it a little ahead of time so the salt definitely needs to be cut down drastically from what the recipe calls for.

text:
i wish i knew to pick out the avocados that are softer before attempting this. i had 2 soft avocados and 1 firm one. the firm avocado was completely impossible to mash. i also think 1/2 cup of onions is too much for 3 avocados. my guac turned out very oniony tasting. when i tried it again w/ half the onions and softer avocados, it was much better. update 3/31/09: i just learned on the food network that if your avocados are too hard, you can grill them for a couple minutes to soften them.

country:
None
text:
Great guacamole! Like many suggested here, I used purple onion instead of white or yellow and only used 1/3 cup. I love onion, though, so next time I will up it to 1/2 cup. I'm not a big fan of tomatoes in guacamole, so I omitted them. In their stead, I added a chopped freshly roasted red pepper. I liked the red color and smokey flavor it added.

We ate it with Bite Size Tostitos, which are very salty chips. I had reduced the salt to 1/2 teaspoon, and it still seemed a little too salty to me. If I make it again and plan to serve it with salted chips, I might completely omit the salt.

text:
The BEST guac I've ever eaten and I can't believe that I made it!  I'm the only avocado fan in my house so I only used 1 avocado, and cut all the other ingredients in half.  Definitely taste as you go...I ended up addding more red pepper for more kick, and left out the cilantro completely (didn't have any...don't care for it much).  And a big BONUS:  because of the lime juice, the guacamole stayed a beautiful green even the next day.  I covered the surface of the guac with plastic wrap, then put the lid on the plastic container and I think that helped keep it nice also.  Thanks SO much...delicious!

I have never gone wrong with this recipe. Guests will ask me ahead of time if I'm making this guacamole. I mash the avocados with a potato masher and add extra tomatoes for a nice chunky texture. Fresh cilantro is best but even the dried stuff works in a pinch. Depending on your tastes you can add more or less onion and garlic - better than anything I've ever had in a restaurant! So easy and so versatile.

As most other reviewers' have said, this is an outstanding fresh guac recipe that is simple and so yummy! city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This was gobbled up by the party goers last night. I noticed a couple of reviews in particular that I'd like to comment on. Someone said to layer the lime juice over the top of the guac rather than mixing it in (to prevent browning). I used the lime juice as directed, and here it is the next day and still no browning. Fresh as can be. Someone else omits tomatoes, because they make the quac "wet" and thus inedible for leftovers. I used my regular garden tomatoes, first removing the seeds and juice, and my leftover guac is still yummy and creamy green perfection (having some for a snack as I write this). I used five large avocados for a party size batch, but kept the other ingredients as is. Only real change I made was to add 2 T. mayo and a bit of cumin. Garnish with a thin lime slice or cilantro sprig and then start on the margaritas!

I am just offering a hint on unripe avocados. You can buy them and use them in 24 hours. Just put them in a brown bag with a banana and fold the bag close I clip it shut, the banana releases ethylene gas which ripens the avocados. Go for it, it works.

text:
The best guac ever! Every time I have made it there are NO leftovers and I double it! I do add only half of the lime juice the recipe calls for after the first time I made it. Also note that by adding the pits from the avocados back into the guac -it keeps it from turning brown so quickly!  THANKS SO MUCH FOR SHARING THIS RECIPE! My friends thank you as well!

text:
Excellent recipe! I personally like to taste the avocado a little more so I use only 1 tomato, 2 tbsp cilantro, 1/3 cup onion, 1/2 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp garlic, along with the lime juice.  I also add 1/2 cup sweet yellow corn.  I make this recipe at parties and it always disappears.  Twice already my guests have asked me to make more.  I might have to start doubling the recipe!  You can play with the recipe like I did to suit your tastes, but it's a great place to start.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this recipe for eons and it is absolutely delicious!  Everyone is always wanting me to make to the guac!  There are one or two variations that you can do for variety.  Instead of the cayenne pepper you can use a favorite picante and the warmer the picante the warmer the guac.  You can also add about 1/2 to 1 cup of sour cream for a "can't stay away from it" version of this time honored recipe.  My family enjoyed it that way at the Sundance restaurant in Red River, New Mexico several years age and it was so good that they want it that way most of the time.  If you are concerned about fat grams, use low or no fat sour cream.  It is hard to beat.  Enjoy!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS GUAC! Best I've ever had, easy. So wonderfully fresh, simple, fun to make, and a total crowd pleaser. I added extra garlic and cilantro, diced my tomatoes and red onion on the chunky side, and mashed the avocados smoothly. The crunch of the onions is perfect, but the key here is the lime. It really adds a special something. 

My first attempt, I made it with just a pinch of cayenne, and my second I tried to up the spiciness by adding more: still delicious, but it wasn't the kind of spice I was looking for. I think next time I'll play around and add finely chopped jalepenos as some reviewers have suggested. Either way: two thumbs up! I foresee myself making this many, many, many  more times.

Great recipe, I am now known for my great guac! :)  Leave avo pits in the guac while it is refrigerated to help keep it fresh (my cousin is a cook gave me that tip). https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2389509.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To keep the guacamole green and fresh, KEEP THE PIT and put it in the center of the guacamole when storing in the fridge. Remove the pit when serving. It sounds like the people who gave this recipe bad reviews aren't too familiar with avocados. If using hass avocados (small, dark green to brown), make sure they are ripe and soft. If they are very firm or hard, they will make a horrible guacamole. Left out on the counter, firm avocados will ripen in 3-4 days.

text:
First attempt @ guacamole.  Not a fan of it, but wanted to bring it to a summer invite to a friends lake home.  everyone thought it was great.  All thumbs up.  Easy.  I say the hardest part of this recipe is finding the perfect ripness of the  avacados.  You want semi soft,  not soft to touch. Roll the room temperature limes with your palm on the counter to juice them up before cutting.  
You must try it!

YUM! This was my first attempt at making guacamole EVER, and it worked out great. I had extremely ripe avocados...I needed to make something! This was easy to do and very flavorful. I think I inadvertently ate about 1/2 of it already...I should probably slow down. I've been making a version of this recipe for a long time- with my own tweeks. I zest the lime after I juice it and mix it with the avo- this adds kick and helps keep the avos from browing as fast. I also add a jalapeno- chopped finely- and I only use red onion b/c I think the flavor is better than a white onion. Hope this helps!

text:
Average.  In real guacamole, if tomatoes and onions are used, they should be finely chopped. Guacamole shouldn't be chunky.  Also, cayenne pepper is no substitute for jalapeno, serano, or some yummy Hatch green chilies. Don't get me wrong. I love cayenne. I use it a lot, but good guacamole requires real chilies.

text:
I've never liked guacamole till I tried this recipe! One thing I learned from my mom is to add a little sour cream. It adds a rich flavor that many people don't recognize, but love! I actually added more lime juice and this stayed a nice green color in my fridge for three days. The only other thing I added was hot sauce and cumin. This is so yummy! My hubby and I are now fans of guac, but only if we make this recipe at home!

Usually I don't follow recipes on here exactly. Typically I read all the reviews and tweak recipes how I think I would like them. For this recipe I did not tweak it at all (unless you count using red onion, but it didn't specify what type) and it was FANTASTIC! I could hardly keep my hands off it until it was time to serve.   I mashed the avocados with the lime juice and salt, and the rest of the ingredients I chopped together in my food processor, then added to the avocados. Soooooo good.

YUMMY! My husband has been craving guacamole lately and I have been tired of buying Whole Foods' yummy, but expensive small tub of guacamole.  Easy to prepare and I used my own fresh cilantro from my herb garden and cherry tomatoes.  I served it with Whole Foods' Restaurant Style tortilla chips (which are heaven!) and my husband and kids wanted to devour it and skip dinner altogether.  Thank you for a glorious recipe!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was one of the best guacamole recipes I've ever tried!  I used 4 avocados instead of 3 to stretch the recipe a bit, and it still tasted great.  Mash 2 of the avocados well, and then keep 2 of the avocados very chunky for a good texture.

I also used a little more lime juice and salt in the recipe to bring out the flavor more.  

If the avocados are not totally ripe, try adding a few tablespoons of sour cream to make it a creamier guacamole.  Enjoy!

country:
None
text:
The best guac I've ever had!  Made this for a family get-together and they loved it!  I used the end of a heavy drinking glass to mash up the avocados in a bowl and it worked great.  The lime juice kept the guac nice and bright for a couple days.  I added a tad less of the cilantro because I'm not a fan of it's "dishsoap" taste and it was still yummy without being overpowered by the herb.  Following advice from other members, I added about a 1 tsp. of cumin.  I had doubled the recipe.  I'll definitely make this again and again.

userID:

Display Name:
LEASTMAN
isPro:

1

50

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/17222.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
MMMM!! This guac is great! I am a huge fan of guacamole and this is the best recipe I have come by so far. Much, much better than store bought mix. Nothing against the mixes, they are great too but I think it's the freshness that makes this recipe so good. I added chopped black olives and used a sweet vidalia onion, although not the whole thing. This is the sort of recipe that you should taste as you go along and do not use any measuring tools. It should be different every time you make it! Also, if you leave one of the avocado pits in the bowl w/the guac, it helps to keep it from turning brown. I use it in addition to the lime juice, but if you don't like lemon or lime, it's a good way to preserve your guac w/o using those. Great recipe! I can't wait for my boyfriend to get home so I can help eat it! Thanks!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2006-03-18T10:53:46.763
helpfulCount:
4

Great recipe BUT be careful with the onion and/or garlic.  Followed the direction exactly and was too oniony/garlicky for my taste.  I wound up adding 2 more avocados and some lemon juice to "fix" it.  Came out great and everyone ate it up.  Next time I'll just omit or reduce the onion and garlic.

text:
Excellent recipe!  Tastes just like the guacamole in an authentic Mexican restaurant when one uses the juice of a lemon instead of that of a lime.  I love guacamole so much that I made it twice (I made it the second time using lemon juice after using lime juice the first time).  Big difference.  The lemon juice gave it more of a kick that was missing when I used lime juice. Just the same, this is a great recipe regardless of the juice that one chooses to use.  Thanks, Bob!

text:
What can I say except that 'look at how many positive reviews are here'. It is a FANTASTIC recipe. However, I 'tweaked' it a little to have been able to keep it for a week without oxidation. I replaced the tomatoes with a very dark green bell pepper and cilantro with Italian parsley. Also, I added white onion and a jalapeno (of course, you can add less if it is too spicy)...and 4-5 cloves of garlic. With so much of vitamin C (from the parsley and some from the bell pepper), the 1-week preservation in my fridge allows me to use it in my salads, on my quinoa burger and whatever strikes my fancy. Oh, and it is so green that it is almost flluorescent...just beautiful!!! Too bad there is only a 5-star max....it deserves five more!

text:
First time trying guacamole.  I thought this was very good and only giving the 4 stars for it "as is" because I haven't made any other to compare.  However, having read the reviews either on this recipe or another, it suggested putting one of the pits in the mix to keep it from turning brown.  Not sure if that is what did the trick, but my guac is now 4 days old and not brown.  For the one who said it gets too soupy, I suggest scooping the seeds, etc. out of the tomatoes as i think maybe another reviewer suggested. Oh...and I read somewhere that when buying your avocados, flick off the stem...if it is brown underneath, don't buy it...it will be "yucky" too.

text:
I was never really a fan of guacamole until my husband tried this recipe. It is fantastic! We go heavy on the cayenne and cilantro, and sometimes don't even use the tomatoes.  It is quick and easy, and tastes so much better than anything you can buy at the grocery store or even most restaurants around here!  To keep it from turning brown so fast, place plastic wrap directly on the guacamole, and press it down to get rid of all the air.

city:

country:

text:
I followed the recipe exactly the first time I made it (except for the cilantro, which I think tastes like soap). I love the flavor overall, and it's super-easy to make! I've made it several times since then, personalizing a bit each time: 1) I add the garlic using a press, so there's no danger of anyone biting into a chunk of raw garlic. 2) I add the lime juice a little at time, because the amount of juice in "one lime" varies (and I ruined a batch by not tasting.) 3)I use less tomato and onion, because I prefer a smoother texture with less "stuff" in it. (Maybe the small avocados I buy are not what was used in the original recipe?) Also, when I made this guacamole today, the avocados had large pits and less fruit, so I also cut back on the salt a little.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Instead of finely minced garlic I just added garlic powder to taste. The minced, uncooked garlic is too bitter for me. If you prefer to use fresh garlic without it being extremely bitter - cut garlic clove in half and take out the middle part that comes out easily. To make the guacamole less watery: 1. salt the onions and set aside because it leeches out the water. Drain when you're ready to add to everything else. 2. Cut the tomatoes in half at the equator and squeeze out the pulp. Dice as usual.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/739882.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe and it was my first time making guacamole from scratch. Only things I have to add to other reviews are: 1) be careful about not adding too many onions, I think 1/2 c is just about the upper limit of my preference, I'd rather make it thicker by adding an extra tomato, or if you really like onions, consider adding onion powder instead, unless you really enjoy raw, diced onions in your recipes. Next time, I would probably add a bit more garlic too. 2) 1 tsp of salt would have been way too much for me, I stopped at 3/4 tsp. and even less would have been desirable. I used 1 extra avocado than the recipe calls for (though mine were smaller in size), and that worked out well. 4) Finally, I substituted fresh parsley for cilantro, I think that either parsley or cilantro are key to  adding a nice flavor to this recipe.

city:

country:
None
text:
Delish!  I used green onion and left out the garlic and cayenne and replaced them with 2 seeded jalapenos.  Since first trying this recipe I have found a fresh salsa sold at Sam's Club that has all the ingredients so now I keep that on hand for making guac.  Just mash avocados, use a slotted spoon to scoop and add the fresh salsa to taste, add salt and lime juice.  It's a real time saver and so delicious.  **A tip - when buying avocados choose those that still have the little end of the stem attached, otherwise the top of the avocado will be brown upon slicing.**

text:
I am famous for my guacamole and salsa (d's salsa-on this site made with mexican style stewed tomatoes instead of plain). I blend 2 of the avocados and cut the other into small chunks for texture. Also blend the onion and one tomato and leave the other tomato in small chunks. I sprinkle cayenne pepper all over the top once everything is blended and then mix it in. Now and then I'll add just a pinch of garlic powder and cumin for some extra flavor but usually I don't add anything!! Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
This is now a staple and I've become "known" for my guac.  It's so fresh... People are always amazed when I share the recipe and they see how easy it is!

I think the best part is how easy it is to 'tweek' for individual tastes.  I have a good friend who loves heat and hates cilantro, so I make a batch heavy on the cayenne with no cilantro for her.  I'm just the opposite, so I make a second batch heavy on the cilantro with no cayenne for me.  Both have a little extra garlic and lime juice as we both love those...

I thought it was very good and tastes like the guacamole in the Mexican restaurants. The only thing I did different was use 1 fresh jalapeno pepper and added one more table spoon of cilantro to give it a little bit more of a kick just like the restaurants. I put all my ingredients into the bowl before I mixed it all together with a fork. The consistency was not as mushy.

I thought the recipe was excellent, but it might be better to add lime juice as you're mashing so you don't end up with too much.  I felt like it was watery and very limey.  I think the avacados I used were on the small side.  If I make it again, I will use less salt, less lime juice (perhaps I'll add some zest).  Overall though, it had spot-on flavor.

With almost 2 thousand reviews I just had to try this one. I am so glad I did! I ate the entire bowl with tortilla chips for lunch!! The only changes I made were I used onion powder and garlic powder because it was faster and easier. So good! Thanks!

text:
Look no further! This is the only guac recipe you will ever need. I have made this more times than I can count - always a huge hit. My family likes chunky guac, so I use a potatoe masher, and try to keep mashing to a minumum. Add lots of medium diced roma tomatoes - definitely seed before chopping or else guac gets too runny. Be bold with extra lime and garlic. I add a few shots of sricha hot chili sauce. All to taste of course. Enjoy!

text:
***Update!! I still make this all the time, but now I use the food processor to chop the tomatoes, onion, cilantro and garlic. I then add the salt and lime juice and let the mixture sit in the fridge for a few hours. 1 hour before serving I mash and add the avocados. This way the flavors blend really well without the avocados browning!!***Delicious! Followed the recipe exactly except I did not add cayenne pepper because I'm not good with spicy. This was delicious and will be my guac recipe from now on! A tip that I learned--buy avocados that are dark in color and soft to the touch--when you cut them they will fall apart easily!

text:
This is truly a great guac recipe.  Every time I make it the crowd goes wild.  My best advice is to just make it to taste though. The taste of this guac also intensifies overnight so don't go crazy adding more ingredients if it seems bland at first. Wait until the next day so you have a better idea of what it's going to taste like.  Also, make a little more than you need so that you can taste it and still have enough for everyone

text:
IF YOU HAVE CHILDREN: Although this recipe is a 5-star as is, I made a few adjustments to accomodate my picky eaters.. 1). Instead of crushing fresh garlic, I substituted the regular salt with garlic salt. 2). Instead of diced onion, I used onion powder. 3). Use LOTS of cilantro! 4). Use chili powder instead of cayenne pepper. I made the recipe using heirloom tomatoes ( my personal preference). This guac is FABULOUS!!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/209766.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the guacamole recipe I've been looking for, and it will now be in my favorite recipes file!  I followed the recipe as written, except I did add 1/2 tsp. cumin and 1/2 serrano pepper (chopped and seeded)for some more spice.  Only complaint was it was a little salty esp. when served with chips, so next time I will put 1/2 teaspoon salt instead of a full teaspoon.  Good tip I read from other reviewers---keep the seeds of the avocado in the guacamole until ready to serve---it really helped prevent it from turning brown! (Even with the seeds in it, though, definitely use it the day you make it, as it is very perishable!)Also, I recommend cutting the cilantro very fine--as you don't want full leaves in the guacamole. Thanks Bob!

This was my first time I made something from avocados. I got nice green firm ones, very expensive and a few hours before potluck I started to make it. WARNING: If you are fist timer with avocados: Dont refrigerate them and buy ripe one. We had to run to the restaurant and by some guacamole. Was cheaper than the avocados I bought. Anyway, I made the recipe a few days later and it took we much longer than the time in recipe. Make sure you cook it a couple of hours before eating, I thought it tasted better after a few hours. It was very good; just I thought the lime tastes dominant. Maybe my lime was too big. My mom thought the lime was too much too. Husband thought it is good. 

Will make it again, but will keep trying some other recipes.

text:
As is, this is not near as spicy as I feel it should be - a pinch of cayenne does nothing - I added a least a teaspoon as well as just as much chipotle chile pepper to kick it up a bit - I also found a whole lime juiced would make it much too watery - I used half if that.  

I also don't mash the avacados - by the time the mixing is done, it's mashed up enough in the end.

text:
I only made 1/2 the recipe and wish I had made it for 4 as listed now.  It is absolutely amazing as promised.  If you only use 1/2 the avacodo, be sure to use the part without the seed.  Place the empty shell from the side you did use over the part you are keeping (with the pit still in it) and wrap both with plastic wrap. It will keep a lot longer for some reason.  

Great recipe and thanks for sharing!  Lorrie

text:
Fantastic!  Just the right blend of spices and I think the cayenne rounds it out perfectly.  I've been searching for the perfect guacamole recipe and now my search is over.  To stretch it to the second day, cover it with plastic wrap, but be SURE the plastic is right on top of the guac, leaving no air.  Then, the next day, simply scrape off the top layer and your guac is good as new:)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been my base guacamole recipe for years and I've made a few changes to my taste that have really turned this into a crowd favorite. I substitute red onion for white and only use 1/2 and for my secret ingredient I add cumin (less than a tsp) for a slightly smokey flavor and always add jalapeo with the seeds removed (usually 2 small or 1 large). The Roma tomato is key to this recipe in my opinion, as it is meatier and holds the flavor so much better. I always cover with Saran Wrap and let the flavor a meld in the fridge for at least two hours before serving, and to avoid any browning of the avacodo, make sure it is sealed tight with no air allowed between the guacamole and the plastic.

text:
OMG!!! I tried this last night and chose this recipe due to the number of ratings and I was NOT disappointed.  I recently fell in love with guac and I've been buying Chipotle's and eating it alone or over their rice, chicken, salsa and beans bowl, and I figured I should probably start making my own.  It was extremely easy to make.  I adjusted the salt and the cayenne pepper.  I did not add as much salt as was called for (I need to watch my sodium intake) and I probably added a bit more than a pinch of cayenne pepper because it's great for weight loss.  P.S.  I use pink Himalayan rock salt which has a better flavor than traditional salt.  Additionally, although I did squeeze the juice of one lime into the bowl, I probably went easy on that too since I'm not a fan of too much lime.  I will be making this on a regular!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2247177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a Texas gal who grew up eating what we call "Tex Mex". I've adapted my guacamole recipe over my span of 68 years and have watched how the favorite restaurants do guacamole table side. I can attest to the fact that this recipe is just about as authentic as it gets for good guacamole in Texas. I know different states offer their own influence (California, Arizona and the Cuban influence in Florida)" but in my humble opinion you HAVE to have onion, tomato, fresh lime juice and cilantro for it to be authentic guac. This recipe brings it all to the table. Yes, plan to buy your avocados a day or two in advance. They should be just slightly soft to the touch with no bruising. If you HAVE to buy hard ones, put them in a brown paper sack for a day or two and they will ripen beautifully. We prefer our guac a little more chunky, so we don't mash the heck out of it. However you like yours, chunky or smooth, this is a no fail recipe. You may need to adjust seasonings based on the size of the avocados. Enjoy!

Great recipe. The cayenne is a good addition if you don't put heat in another place. But, I love heat. Far superior to store bought "fresh" guacamole.

text:
There is NEVER a pre-packaged container of store bought guacamole or mix to which you add avacados in my house after making this recipe.  It doesn't take long and the accolades from family and guests is amazing.  (Isn't that what every cook wants?) If I don't make this for every gathering I get stared down.  Made this during a multi-family vacation in Myrtle Beach.  It was gone in less than 5 minutes.  Made it the next day, doubled the recipe, and it didn't even make it to the fridge for the 1 hour.  I'd give it 6 stars.

country:
None
text:
Since I started using this recipe, I'm forbidden from ever bring home store bought guac!  I lower the salt to 1/2 tsp. as another reviewer suggested - 1 tsp. was too much for us.   I use red onion and if I have a jalapeo, that's a happy addition to toss in.  Either buy avocadoes in advance, or find a grocery store with a good Spanish-Latino cooking section.  You won't be putting up with slimy cilantro or rock hard avocados.

country:
None
text:
I made this as written with two exceptions: I put about 3/4 tsp ground cumin in it, and I used green onions instead of yellow or red. This batch had great flavor with lots of lime juice in it. My old recipe may be slightly better, as it has 4 T. salsa in place of the garlic and tomato of this recipe, but the salsa (freshly made) has more depth  of flavor (green pepper, jalapeno, onion, tomatoes, red wine vinegar, tomato paste, garlic). But I will use this recipe sometimes, because it is almost as good and easier to make than my old pair of recipes (salsa, guac). Thanks! BTW, I made this a second time using Vidalia onion in place of green onions, but it wasn't nearly as good. If you like green onions, they are a must!

This is a fabulous recipe! It is so fresh and bursting with flavour. I added 1/2 a seeded jalapeno for more kick and my family enjoyed it very much. userID:
6969483
Display Name:
dawn
isPro:

20
favoritesCount:

0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this several times exactly as written and my whole family loves it!  Actually, I have to double the recipe...and it makes alot!  This is good with the obvious tortilla chips, but also on Vegan Tacos!  Yummy!  I typically use iodized sea salt, but I did use Pink Himalayan Sea Salt once (I had a couple little samples) and I must say it was out of this world!  Instead of juicing a lime, I use 1T of Real Lime Juice to save some time.  A "pinch" of cayenne is 1/4 tsp, but you can always add more to your taste ~ I recommend starting with this amount.  This is a must try recipe!

text:
I've been making guacamole with a very similar recipe for years with rave reviews! I make sure to remove the tomato insides...reduces liquid amount in mixture. Also, I use green onions. I find that taste is more to my liking. Finally, I use a guacamole seasoning mix. It really adds some flavor to the dip, but I'm sure enough salt would do the trick as well. Cilantro is really the secret to this guacamole!

Display Name:
Reets

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I scaled down the recipe a bit because I made it to top hamburgers, and not for a dip.  I followed the directions for the most part, but as I didn't have lime, I substituted lemon.  It's not quite the right flavour, but it gave the avocado a little kick.  Also, I didn't have fresh cilantro, so I used 1 Tbsp ground coriander instead (I figured it should have the same flavour).  If you're making this and it's runny, make sure you use plum tomatoes, as directed.  Other tomato varieties are too fleshy; however, you could scoop out the insides and just use the tomato shell if that's what you have in your fridge.  Personally, I like onions, so this was great for me...but if you find yellow onions to be too strong, try a couple of green onions, or just use less onion (and grate it to keep it small).

text:
I have made this recipe many, many times.  I absolutely love it, but I have made some modifications to the recipe to suit my own taste.  I add about 2 tsp of finely minced onion instead of the 1/2 cup, and I add half of a tomato instead of 2 full tomatoes, plus I also skip the cayenne.  With these changes, the guacamole stays creamy and is very easy on the palate.  Love it!

text:
Ok to start off with I want to say up front that I love this recipe as it is written, and I know some of you out there think you shouldn't rate something if you change it.  With that said in my opinion a recipe is a guideline to follow and you make changes to suit you individual taste and I have to say that this is the best guacamole recipe i have ever made.  Yes I did change a few things but again i made it to suit my family's taste and they absolutly loved it. The only changes I made was: cut the salt in half (also used seasoned salt instead) added 1 finely chopped jalepeno, doubled the garlic, used green onions (only because it was use them or lose them) and doubled the cilantro.  This is a great easy recipe that everyone will love!

This recipe is SUPERB.  I did not follow the measurements.  I wanted a colourful guacamole so I just added the ingredients and tasted as I went along.  The first time I made it, I added garlic.  I have skipped out garlic ever since because it just tastes better without it.  I also add in some paprika to up the flavour a little bit more. :)  Thank you so much for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My fiancee and our best man raved that this was, "restaurant worthy, if not better!"     I took a lot of tips from previous reviewers and this is what I came up with: 2 mashed avocados, 1 cut into tiny cubes, add 1/4-1/2 tsp cumin, leave out the seeds of the tomatoes, extra garlic and onions, leave the pits of the avacadoes in the guac and instead of mixing in the lime juice, just layer it over the top of the guac til ready to serve, then stir well. LOVE IT!!

text:
This was insanely good.  I used small hass avocados for this, lessened the salt a bit, and omitted the pepper.  Definitely use a fresh lime and fresh garlic-- this makes all the difference.  Anyway, I intended to eat some of this on a good bread with a friend as a snack, but we ended up making the bread + guac a full lunch.  We literally couldn't stop eating the guac because it tasted so good, and ended up finishing a whole loaf of bread, not because we were hungry, but because we didn't want to stop eating the guac!  This is definitely a dangerous recipe if you're on a diet.

I made this recipe to go with fajitas, beans and spanish rice. This is my first time to do guacamole and I actually do not like avocados, so I made it (following the recipe, put much less onion in it, and couldn't find cayenne pepper) without ever tasting it.   My husband who is at home with everything Mexican and Tex-Mex, said that it was really good. I asked him for future references, if there was anything he would change about it, and he said NO!!!    So, it must be good. I will keep the recipe and do it again!

Wow, it was awesome to see something close to my recipe that made real guacamole-chunky like it should be.  I do up the tomatoes to 3 and use a red onion, plus instead of cayenne, I use hot sauce and add in onion powder and garlic powder & salt & pepper to taste. Also, one big main ingredient missing is cilantro.  I chop a couple handuls and toss it in - really adds an extra zing! My uncle is from Mexico and he helped me perfect my recipe and this is almost exact - yum - great recipe!

I followed the recipe almost exactly - one of my avocados was bad :( so I only used 2, and my lime was a little hard so I probably only got about half the juice of a regular lime; but I thought it was just about perfect - from now on I will use 3 avocados and the juice of half a lime.  Thanks so much!

text:
Not that this recipe needs another review but I have made it so many times now, it seemed only right to rate it.  Everyone I have made this for loves it too!  I love the proportions as they are, though I sometimes add a bit more garlic.  My son loves this guacamole without the cilantro - he`s not a fan so if you aren`t either you can omit it and still have great guacamole.  Personally I think the cilantro adds excellent flavor.  Don`t be afraid to use a little cayenne if you`re not sure; that`s what I did the first time and it added just a little kick.  No other guacamole recipes that I`ve tried are as good as this one.  Thanks for sharing a great recipe!!

text:
This is the best guacamole I have ever had.  I  used Rotel cilantro and lime.  To keep it fresh in the fridge, I kept one avocado seed in the mixture.  I don't know why but it helps it maintain the bright green color.  Also, to stay heart healthy and carb-free, take a chicken breast dry seasoned with Mrs. Dash fiesta lime and grill it, then top this guacamole on top.  Delicious!

text:
This recipe is almost identical to the one I've been making for years. The reason I'm only giving it 3 stars is because it is missing one of the most important ingredients... JALAPENO!!! Oh my goodness. It's so ridiculous that this recipe has such great reviews despite the fact that it's missing something so critical. I think the cayenne is unnecessary and minced jalapeno be substituted in its place. Just a small amount is needed for taste, and for those of us who love hot, hot, hot, at least one full jalapeno should be added. Additionally, the recipe should specify that it is sweet red onion that should be used. Hope this helps.

Very good and very easy... I've used this recipe several times. I like to cube one of the avocados and fold it in after I've thoroughly mixed all the other ingredients, the result is both smooth and chunky. Sometimes, I'll sautee the onion first so it's not so bitey... makes the dish that much more special.

text:
This is so good and so easy to make. Try not to make it too early in advance because it turns brown within 2 hours sitting in room temperature. Store in the fridge with a tight seal helps to slow it down from turning brown a little bit. My friend suggested to keep the avocado pits in the guacamole might keep it from turning brown quickly. Will definitely make this again and again....

text:
Best homemade quacamole I've ever made. Left out the cayenne pepper and minced garlic (actaully forgot to put the garlic in) but added a little cumin and garlic powder for some added flavor. Let it sit in fridge for about a half hour for flavors to meld and that was just fine. Also note that by leaving the avocado seeds in quac will keep it fresher and from turning brown...I left 2 seeds in there as well as made sure plenty of lime juice.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Easy and delicious recipe.  I've made this recipe 3 times already and everyone loves it.  Here are some of my deviations: I am not a big onion fan, so I only use 1/4 to 1/3 cup of onions; if you want more heat, use 3-4 pinches of cayenne pepper; and if you don't have fresh cilantro, use 3 teaspoons of dried cilantro.  I also don't use any salt since I normally eat it with tortilla chips which are almost always salted already.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-04-06T06:34:44.213
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
3332818
Display Name:
Wendy Iuliano
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
83
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6397122.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This guacamole was so good, my family ate it up in minutes.  I bought a netted bag with 5 small avocados and used them all. They were black and soft and when I peeled them they were already turning a bit brown, but they were easy to mash (I used a potato masher), and tasted great.  It is hard judging which avocados to buy, but the riper the better. I used the 1/2 cup of onion and didn't find it overpowering at all. I also added an extra tspn of minced garlic, and chopped up a jalepeno pepper(did not make it hot at all), and only used 1/2 squeezed lime(a whole lime would have been too overpowering.  My one daughter does not like cilantro, so I divided the guac in 1/2 before adding the cilantro (only used 1 tspn of cilantro, since it was divided) and both bowls were eaten up. I made this about 3 hours ahead of time, and while it tasted very good when I served it, it did taste better, I thought right away after I made it. Refrigerating it, it lost some of the taste I found.  Great easy recipe, will definitely make again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a WONDERFUL recipe. I LOVED it. I have read all the reviews and I have noticed that no one said anything about how to get the pit out...I cut my avocado in two, then I take my sharp knife and hit it into the pit and turn sideways and out pops the pit. Then instead of peeling the avocado, I simply spoon it into my bowl. (or) invert the peel and the (ripe) avocado can pop into the bowl too. As to the recipe...I wouldn't change a thing, other than to say, I always put the pits in the bowl when all is mixed up. The lime juice & the pits  keep it from turning brown. Works every time also, ALWAYS put leftovers in an air tight container IF, that is, you have any left. Thanks for the wonderful recipe!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To prevent the avocadoes from browning, peel them and put them into some water with ice in it. Let them sit in there while you chop your cilantro, tomatoes and onions and whatever else you add. Drain off the water and then mash them. This keeps them nice and green for a long time. If you have leftovers try storing in an airtight container and at the most there is a thin dark green layer which you can scrape off if it bothers you. I don't remember where I learned this but I know it works.

text:
I must say, this took a lot of work! However, it was definitely worth it. I find it not necessary to make any alterations on this recipe. If you like chunky guacamole, this is the perfect recipe for you. The combination of spices was pleasant to the tongue, unless you don't like a little kick. Don't try to make too much if you don't plan on eating it within a week. But overall, I thought this was absolutely delicious and is worth to make if you have a large amount of free time.

text:
Fantastic recipe!

After trying this many times, I liked it best with 1/3 cup onion and 1 tbsp of garlic.  I don't like cilantro so I dropped it.  Cayenne to taste and salt until the avocado flavor stands out nicely.

Buy the avos at the point where they give a little with a squeeze.  Then ripen them in a paper bag with apples for 12-16 hours and they'll be perfect.

Amazing recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/86545.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely, HANDS DOWN, the BEST gucamole recipe EVER. I actually learned this recipe from a few waiter friends I knew that worked at this AMAZING Mexican joint. The key, and I seriously mean this, is good avocados. This is ALL ABOUT the avocados. Don't bother to use this recipe if you don't have good, creamy, ripe ones. It will turn out chalky and unpleasant. If your avocados aren't ripe yet, stick them in newspaper with a banana in a cupboard for a few days. If you insist on using bad avocados I would suggest adding some sour cream and a couple of teaspoons of olive oil and they should improve the taste.
Review:

None
country:
None
text:
WOW! The first time I made this recipe, it came out so disappointing, I figured I'd just buy the store bought seasoning forever. I decided to try it again since I was craving avocado. It's amazing! I used 2 large avocados, no cilantro, 1 minced jalapeno, the juice of 1/2 a lime, 1-2 large pinches of cumin, and used a can of drained, diced tomatoes instead of roma. The rest of the recipe I kept the same. So amazing, I'm so glad I tried it again! Tweak this recipe to your liking and you can't go wrong. **Update: I've also used 1 avocado and 3/4 can pureed white beans and it makes a yummy lighter version. Both versions are great depending on what you're looking for. Season to taste!

text:
This was good, but not as great as I was expecting it to be. I must've had a large lime because the lime juice flavor was extremely overpowering. It was somewhat of a disappointment as I was bringing this to a party and couldn't seem to correct the problem. I tried adding some hot sauce to cut back on the lime flavor but it didn't work out very well. What I really needed, but did not have, was another avocado that I could have mashed up and blended in. So... just heed this warning: Be aware of the size of the lime you're using for this dish so you don't ruin what would have otherwise been some really good guacamole!

Very good! A spur-of-the-moment inspiration led me to add little honey (especially since I was making slightly spicy chips to go with it), and it definitely improved the guac to have the hint of sweetness.  I had this, a storebought bottle of salsa, and a tub of storebought sour cream with homemade chips when I had some friends over for dinner.  The salsa was untouched, and I got constant comments that the sour cream and guac went very well together.  A definite success!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/15729.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent guacamole! I used dried cilantro, as my grocery store was out of fresh. I thought all the ingredients were perfectly proportioned, but the amount of onion you use should depend on personal preference and the strength of the onion. Also, finely mincing an onion (garlic or pepper) will make the flavor more pungent, so take care when chopping. Additionally, the cayenne pepper can be scaled to your preference or omitted entirely. I substituted it with 1 seeded and finely chopped jalapeno. I used the guacamole on chicken quesadillas, and dipped we tortilla chips in the leftovers. Great!

text:
I make guacamole for my family's weekly mexican dinner night.  Last week I thought I would try a new recipe, so I pulled this one up.  I was a little skeptical about the large amount of lime juice and salt...so I only added a little at a time.  I ended up using half a lime, 1/2 tsp salt, and 1/2 tsp garlic and my family LOVED it.  This way you don't overpower the avacado. Cilantro is a great addition :)

I really never liked guacamole... that being said, I like this recipe a lot!  I used bottled lime juice (2t), two slices of onion and 2 slices of tomato, diced, and no cayenne.  we don't like cilantro, so I left it out.  I would think that anyone could start with this basic recipe and have a successful batch of guacamole in no time!

text:
LOVE this recipe! I always add more lime, and it also helps to keep it from browning so quickly. If you dont want to take the time to cut up the onions, tomatoes, cilantro, etc., I recommend buying a container of fresh pico de Gallo! Itll save you lots of time, and you should still get the same desired result! I also add a little bit of chili powder, and a touch of cayenne for that added spice.

Oh. My. Goodness. So usually I just 'wing it's and add stuff until it tastes good enough to eat. And it never turns out like i hope it would. But following this recipe turned out PERFECT. I halved it, because it was just my husband and me. I also do not trust my knife-cutting skills, so I used a hand-powered food processor. 

My husband is of mexican descent and is really picky on his mexican food. And his fruits. And his vegetables. Basically he doesn't like anything that comes from the ground. I chopped this up and gave him a small sample and he LOVED it. He wanted a second taste. He said I WILL EAT THIS BY ITSELF. So yeah, its pretty good. Definitely a keeper. I literally made an account with this site just to write a review. 15/10.

Excellent an authentic tasting recipe. My kids absolutely loved the flavor of this guacamole. Its rather simple to make, but the key to it is the quality of the avocados you use. Id highly suggest that you buy fully ripened avocados, or purchase your avocados at least three days prior to making the guacamole to have the best tasting guacamole possible.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe (well, 5 batches worth), but added extra lime juice, cut the salt in half, and cut the onions about in half.  I made it the day before a party, and when I arrived it was delicious and everyone was raving about it.  If you have to prepare it a day ahead and don't want it to turn brown (like avocados do), store in a tall narrow container to limit the surface area that is exposed at the top, and top with a layer of lime juice.  Mine was as perfectly green the next day as it was when I made it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is amazing guacamole that I've made at least half a dozen times. The best suggestions from reviews that I have incorporated are:
a) double or triple the garlic (to taste)
b) double the cilantro
c) smash all but one avacado, then cut the last into 1/4" chunks and stir into the mix
d) add a finely chopped jalapeno pepper
e) cover the completed guacamole with plastic wrap and chill in the fridge for an hour.

text:
I have made this guacamole several times, minus the cilantro.  It is my go to guacamole, very easy to put together and very fresh tasting.  It will keep nicely in the refrigerator for a day or two as long as you place an avocado pit in the guacamole after it is first prepared.  I do like to add a fresh diced jalapeo to the recipe as well as the cayenne pepper to add some spiciness.

Very simple recipe. All the metrics and ratios are great. It's plain. But on the mark. I used the viatmix for about 5 pulses because I like it smoother. I have been making this recipe for almost a year now and this recipe NEVER seems to fail me. If I want guacamole and I don't have ripe enough avocados, I will leave them in a brown paper bag for about 6 hours or so in a slightly warm place and they will soften right up. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this guac the first time exactly like the recipe stated.  It is very good as is.  This time around I adjusted it to my family's taste.  I used 5 avacados that were a little too ripe so I had to make it smooth style.  I almost doubled the tomatoes and oniions.  I used half red and half yellow onion.  The red tangs it up quite a bit.  I used one good shake of cayenne for each avacado.  I also used about 1/2 the salt (1/2 tsp).  I used CLINK1833's suggestion and added a jalapeno (deveined and deseeded).  I also used 2 whole cloves of garlic.  I used the juice of one lime, but will add some fresh for each use over the next day or so to freshen it up.

I've made this recipe approximately 5 times now for family parties. No changes to the recipe. It's always a hit when I make it. I personally don't like cilantro but everyone who's eaten the guacomale says it's delicious and there usually isn't any left by the time the main course is served.

text:
This is great as is.  Simple, easy and delicious.  I have made it as written many times but have recently been adding a few things.    
I add a few chopped Jalapeos and a bit of cumin to suit my tastes.  And I have some sort of weird addiction to salt so I add a bit more.  Some people think this recipe has to much salt but I disagree.  We all have different tastebuds as we all know.  I wish all recipes were this simple.  Now, to just plant that  avocado tree.

I tried this per the recipe & thought it was salty & bland.  So I added what I thought it needed & it was great. text:
I am going middle ground here, since my husband liked it, but I didn't. There was something off-putting about this, and I can't figure out what it was. I made sure the avocados were ripe, but not too ripe; and did everything as stated. Somehow there was something very bitter about this, and I can't figure out if it was the garlic, the salt, the acid from the lime juice; I just don't know. I put in a ton more cayenne because I like the kick, and ditto that for the addition of two jalapenos... but somehow I just didn't care for it in the end :\ With that said, I added a teaspoon of sugar to try to cut the bitter and I STILL disliked it. So, I give up. The hubby can eat it, and I'll just stick to eating other dips.

text:
This is the first guacamole recipe I have ever tried, and I'm not sure I will ever try another.  I follow directions with one exception - I add the juice of 1/2 of a lime more to the recipe, regardless of what serving size I am making. I have made it 4 times since the first, sometimes smooth, sometimes chunky. Great on grilled chicken, w/ corn chips, or used as a spread on turkey/bacon sandwich. Exploring more serving suggestions today. Love it!

text:
Very healthy and preservative free.  Love it!  Very quick and easy to make.  I discovered that putting clear plastic wrap over the guacamole and making sure to leave no air pockets from edge to edge of the container will prevent the guacamole from oxidizing and turning brown. But also make sure to seal the lid after putting the wrap and refrigerate.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe as written. We always use fresh cilantro. However, we've used lime juice out of the bottle and used lemon juice once when the lime ran out. Best when using all fresh ingredients. We also add more garlic to suit our taste. We think it tastes better when made and chilled for a couple of hours while the ingredients meld together. If you have leftovers or are making the day before, save one pit and push into the middle to keep the color from turning brown. We tried once to spray lime juice on the top, but the pit works much better.
Thanks for sharing.

I was craving Guacamole and my local favorite store only makes it on weekends!  I immediately came to allrecipes because I love that there are reviews from real people.

This recipe did what we needed it to do.  Based on reviews, we added cumin and jalapenos (dice)   This is delicious!  We decided to stick it in the fridge as the avocado had been sitting in a sunny window.  We are letting the flavors blend and cannot wait to snack on this tonight!  Thank you so much for sharing this!

This recipe is a WINNER!  I can't tell you how many times I've had guacamole that was just so-so.  Yuck.  This recipe kicks it up a notch with onion, garlic, cilantro and lime.  I mash up the avocado so it's about 75% smooth and leave the tomatoes fairly chunky, say 60%. I like texture.  I'm a texture girl.  A good guacamole recipe will make you very popular with your friends and family.  This guacamole is paired with a good organic chip.  Spectacular.

text:
I followed this recipe to a T and it turned out great! It was my first time making guacamole and this recipe was easy to follow. I was somewhat nervous about being able to find ripe avocados that were ready-to-use; I haven't had much luck in the avocado department. However I did a little research beforehand and basically the way to tell if the avocado is ripe is my squeezing it. It'll be distinctly "softer"/easier to squeeze than the others. At least that's how I figured it out. :)

text:
i'm one who generally prefers to make simple recipes (such as this or hummus) based off taste preference from scratch, but i decided to give this one a shot based off the awesome reviews and ratings. i never have thought to add lime juice to the guac i usually would make- that was a nice, zesty touch! but i have to give it 4 instead of 5 stars because i don't think the onion really fit in with it. next time i will use onion powder instead of diced onion- i think it was a texture issue but i think the powder would fit better for the flavor. i also was not a huge fan of diced tomatoes in this. i thought it took away some of the appeal. oh, and a touch of cumin made it perfect! otherwise, great recipe and glad i tried it out! one i will make again with some modifications... thanks for sharing!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe, everytime I've made it everyone loved it. I use red onion and make sure to chop it finely but add a bit less than half a cup (maybe a 1/3 of a cup) as I don't like raw onion to be overpowering. I figure you can always add more if not strong enough.  I don't find the onion is too strong in this dish if you let it sit for a couple hours. I've also made it with diced jar jalepenos as well rather than the cayenne pepper. Used baby Roma tomatoes about 8. I've served it with raw vegetables, homemade pita chips and also with corn chips. Delicious!

text:
This recipe is fantastic!! I did however add some jalapenos, cumin (1 tsp)and a also doubled up on the garlic.. you wont be disappointed!! :)

I've notice  a few people say to to leave an avocado pit in the guacamole to keep it from turning brown.. After a little research I have found that the key is not the pit but rather preventing oxidation.. simple solution is to press plastic wrap tightly to the guacamole.. hope this helps!!!

text:
I never cared for guacamole. Then a friend of mine asked me to taste some she made. It was good, so I searched for a recipe. I found this one and now I love guacamole!  The garlic is a key ingredient. I added a little more garlic and a little extra lime juice than the recipe calls for.  This is the ONLY guacamole I will eat!!  Oh yeah, for some reason the organic cilantro seemed to be a little more potent than the other.  This is quick and easy to make too.

text:
The ONLY negative I've found with this recipe is that you will likely begin to get tired of making it because once you do, that is ALL that you'll ever be asked to make again for a party.  I don't change a thing... it needs to tweaking.  Make sure to use fresh limes and fresh cilantro... it makes a HUGE difference.  Also, for those afraid of heat or thing the cayenne is actually "optional"... my opinion is that is what separates this guacamole from the rest.  It adds a depth of flavor that shouldn't be missed and there is liitle "heat", just a friendly little kick.  As the old commercial says... try it, you'll like it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!  I have never been a guac fan until I had some made fresh right before my eyes at a place in St. Louis.  Ever since I have been on the hunt for a good recipe and here it is.  Made it for a family gathering and I made sure I got the remaining bit left at the end of the day.  The only adjustments we made were dried minced garlic which we eye-balled (we love garlic so we added plenty) and added extra cayenne for more heat.  To maintain its bold flavors, it's best to serve cold.  If serving at room temp, make sure your chips aren't too salty because the chips seemed to overpower the guac.  Thanks for a great recipe!

city:
