region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious! I made it for a spanish project and my teacher kept coming back to get more! Even kids who were skeptical about guacamole tried it and liked it! I did change some things about the recipe, though. I started with 1 lime, but added another one because I thought it needed more, I also only did about half a tomato but that's just personal taste. I would probably use a little less salt,  because I ended up having to go out to the store and buy another avocado because it was too salty. Also, I suggest using red onions if you're not a huge onion person. It is a lot milder, and add some more color to the guacamole. Anyway, overall I thought this was delicious and would make it again in a heartbeat.

This is a very good beginner recipe for guacamole.  For a little more robust flavor you could try making any or all adjustment:  2 cloves of garlic (pressed or mince) 1 roasted red pepper half - chopped 1/2 teaspoon Cumin 1 teaspoon Oregano Pinch or ground black pepper Jalepeno-seeded and chopped

text:
This had a great flavor and texture.  I omitted the tomatoes, based on preference, and added a few pinches of cayenne.  Next time, I might cut the lime juice back to half a lime - I found the favor a little strong, but the lime juice also helps prevent the guacamole from browning.  I might also add a little garlic powder to intensify the flavor (it might have had more garlic flavor if I had let it sit longer before serving).

userID:
864515
Display Name:
NPINCEK
isPro:

19
favoritesCount:
73
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was a good start. I think my additions made it really delicious. I used half of the onion because I find that it overpoweres the other flavors.  I added a finely chopped seeded jalapeno pepper instead of the cayenne pepper.  I also seeded the tomatoes before chopping. That way the guacamole doesn't get too soupy. I used Lawry's seasoned salt instead of regualr salt. Mix all ingredients except for avocado. (If the avo is ripe enough you don't need to chop it - just scoup it out.) Then add ripe/soft avocado last and keep stirring and mashing until desired consistency.  I have tried chopping the ingredients in the food processor a few times  but it never tastes as good as chopping everything by hand. I don't know why.  Yummy!

text:
Great starter recipe for one to tweak to their own taste - Guacamole is just a salsa made from avodcado, so you can make it any way you like.  The lime juice will slow the oxidation of the avocado, but you can also use lemon juice.  Add some jalapenos for kick - its good without garlic too (and I'm a garlic lover).

Thank you! I didn't think I liked guacamole till I had some home made a few weekends ago and decided maybe I just didn't like the stuff they serve at the restaurants I've had it at. I used this one as a guide, did not add cilantro (husband doesn't like it) or tomato, as the home made version I tried that I discovered i liked didn't have them in it.  Was great and I used it in a 7 layer taco dip for the girls at work.  I plan to tweak this to our liking and am happy to learn I do like something I thought I didn't. Thank you!

This is almost exactly the recipe I came up with when I took a shot in the dark at making guac from scratch. From New Mexico, where we know our guacamole:  AWESOME!  Only change was to add some spicy New Mexican salsa, cutting back the tomatoes a bit, as the salsa had tomato in it.  Make sure you use all of the lime; it adds a wonderful, fresh zestiness and keeps the guac from turning black--even by the next day!  Thanks, Bob!

text:
This was really excellent.  I took it to a women's party and got many rave reviews.  My only complaint is that the recipe says it will serve 4 people, so I doubled it.  However, I altered it a little bit as I saw fit:  I only put 1.5 limes in, instead of 2; 3 romas instead of 4.  I thought the lime flavor was far over powering (but I liked it for my taste).  And it ended up serving about 15 people at the party, and I still had a full bowl (15ish servings) to take home!  It did not brown at all for me the next day, which was a plus because I enjoyed it so much!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
OH. MY. GOD. I just made this and it really is the greatest guacamole ever. I changed a few things, however. Instead of three avacados I used four haas avacados, only used half the salt, and to cut down on time, I used half a can of petite diced tomatoes. And I also marinated the cilantro, garlic, and onion in lime juice as another reviewer did. 


Here's a tip I learned from my father: leave an avacado seed in your guacamole to keep it from turning brown if you plan on putting it in the fridge. It'll keep it fresh. 

Thanks for the AWESOME recipe!!

text:
I've made it several times.... exactly by the recipe and it is FANTASTIC!  The last 2 times I made it, I put the garlic, onion and cilantro in the bowl first and marinated it with half of the lime juice for a few minutes as I was cutting open the avocados. I added everything else and the rest of the lime juice and mashed it all together... adding the tomatoes last. It was PERFECTO! Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Delish-- got rave reviews at the party it was taken to, and was gone before I knew it. I could not find fresh cilantro, no matter how hard I looked, so I added a tablespoon or two of salsa verde to give it some extra flavor, and some extra garlic. I processed the avocados, onions (I have an aversion to biting into raw onion), and garlic with the salsa verde and lime juice in my food processor until reasonably smooth, then mixed the tomatoes in my hand. Making this again soon!

text:
Most people tell me this is the best guacamole they've ever had.  I have to agree.  Any time there is a party, or pot luck, or get-together, I'm asked to make this recipe.  Thanks Bob!!!

I do add a diced jalapeno to the recipe to spice the recipe up a bit more.  I also use more cayenne pepper than recommended.  Feel free to add an extra roma tomato, and don't forget the cilantro and garlic!!!  Some people say they don't like that stuff, but it makes the recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm from California and this is how I have always made guacamole. It's best to make this and let it sit overnight to blend the flavors. The lime juice will keep it from turning brown. However, if you are not a big fan of lots of lime or lemon juice, drop one of the avacado pits on top of the dip once it is made and cover with plastic wrap. The pit will also keep the dip from turning brown. Remove the pit then stir just before serving.

text:
My Dad has always made wonderful guac, I was skeptical that being a native San Diegan I would find the best Guacamole I have ever tasted, but I did.  This is WONDERFUL!  You can eat it right away, but I found it key to let the lime juice, onion, garlic, and cilantro flavors mix for an hour or so in the fridge.  Even better than Su casa's fresh table side guacamole.  USE FRESH INGREDIANTS... I have made it three times in the past 3 days, and I used some onion that wasnt quite fresh and it wasnt as good.  I also subbed air loom tomatoes, but they werent as good as the Roma.  I dont know if you can improve this recipe if you try.. although maybe a sqeeze of orange which I will try next time.

Display Name:
Elizabeth Chappuis

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  My own version is very similar and everyone  raves over it, even those who say they hate guacamole.  Two things I do differently.  This recipe needs some spice and I use one habanero per four or five avacados (pray you don't get a really hot pepper and dice it VERY finely).  I tried jalapeno peppers but they still didn't overcome the blandness.  The second thing I do is after you blend all the ingredients you add club soda to the consistency of your liking-no matter how firm your avacodos are you can get the same consistency each time and somehow the soda water really melds the flavors together.  Chill before serving.  I don't normally use garlic or cayenne but it sounds like a good idea and I'll try the garlic next time!  Cayenne and a habanero would be way too much heat.  The sweetness of red onion helps balance out the spiciness of the pepper.  Shhhhh!  Don't tell anyone about the club soda secret!

5

text:
I have made this very guacamole for years.  It is the only way to make it right and most authentic.  Sometimes I add a dash of cummin. For company I mix all of these ingredients except the tomatoes, cilantro and onion - out that to the side.  Put the guacamole in a pretty bowl and make a hole in the center of the mixture.  Mix the diced onion, tomatoes and cilantro and place in the middle of the guacamole.  It is a very pretty presentation and for those who don't like onion etc...they can still dip arount that part.

text:
This is a great base recipe.  I would have given it 5 stars, but I did so many modifications to it, that I feel that wouldn't be fair to people who just look at the ratings when deciding on a recipe.  
I skipped the lime, added some lemon juice instead. It tastes better (in my opinion) and it prevents browning.  I upped the amount of minced garlic and added chopped jalepeno.  For spiced I used pepper, garlic salt, cumin and cayenne.

text:
Ive been all over the country trying guacamole when I happen to find a Mexican restaurant. My wife and I simply love guacamole and this is the best we have ever had. We consistently make this at home, for get together with friends, and any other excuse we can find to make this recipe. I generally quadruple the amount of everything because I need a large amount to feed the masses. This guacamole recipe has converted guacamole haters young and old. Ive made it so many times now that I dont need the recipe anymore. We like it chunky, not a Madagascar reference, just our preference! This is sure to be a hit for one or twenty-five people.

text:
I'd recommend mixing all your core ingredients first then adding the salt, cayenne and cumin to taste. I did that and it turned out great. I find it doesn't hurt to go pretty heavy with the cayenne but a little bit of cumin goes a long way. Basically just a dash. I'd also recommend fine ground sea salt rather than regular table salt.

text:
Used 6 Avacados, increased salt to 2 tsp, added 3 Jalapeos seeded, deveined, and minced.  Before processing, I finely chopped the onion and placed it in the bottom of the mixing bowl followed by the avacados, jalapeos and salt, using a hand potatoe masher to chop, mix and cream the mixture.  Next came the tomatoes, and cilantro (a complete bunch with stems trimmed off).  A nice heaping of Mexican Cheese at the table to meet your taste.

This was sooooo good. I followed the recipe except I forgot the garlic - oops but it was still very good. We absolutely loved it with our sweet and spicy chicken wraps and tortilla chips. It was the perfect side dish.  I loved the kick it gave as you took your bite and began to chew. The freshness from all the ingredients really made this stand out. I have to say though growing up with avocado tress were a little fanatic about all things avocado. I will make it this way from now on. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Pretty much followed the directions as written,.  I did cut back a bit on the salt and onion which I minced fine.  I personally don't like biting into a chunk of raw onion.  I did kick it up a notch by adding a 1.2 pound of freshly boiled shrimp cut into small pieces.  I boiled the shrimp for 5 minuted in old bay style seasoning then chilled after draining,  Real nice addition, guests loved it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW!!! this is a great, easy, no frills guacamole that is just spot on. 
The only deviation from the recipe was in my technique. after chopping the onion, cilantro and garlic, I sprinkled some kosher salt and mashed/mixed it together for a few minutes with my chefs knife (kind of like mincing garlic) until it was like a paste. then mixed my paste like mixture with the avocados, tomatoes and fresh lime juice. Voila, simply incredibly good guacamole!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for a friend, and while she has not tried it yet, I have. I liked it, but I have made a few edits that I will be using when I make it again, and you can use it too! 

I put in a tiny dash of extra lime juice, only half a teaspoon of salt instead of a full one. I also put in about a teaspoon of the cayenne instead of the estimated 1/8 of a teaspoon, and about 1/8 tsp. of ground cumin. 

My only qualm was the cilantro. 3 Tbsp is D E F I N I T E L Y too much in my opinion. Next time I make this I will be putting in about a teaspoon instead. 

Over all, I liked it!

This was so easy and tasty....but I did make some changes as suggested by other reviewers:  added 1/2 tsp. white vinegar, about 1 tsp. sour cream, about 2 Tblsp. my favorite salsa and, since I didn't have lime, I used lemon juice instead...about 1 Tblsp.  I only used 2 large Haas avocadoes so my measurements were 'eye-balled' so texture did not get too thin.  Very good stuff!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent! My husband and I both loved it! 
I did not add any salt.  The chip rounds that I used for dipping had enough salt.  We also added a pinch of cumin as others mentioned.  Very very tasty.  Thanks for the recipe!  
I read that if you are not using right away to refrigerate and cover with saran.  Ensure the saran is touching all the top surface of the guacamole to prevent discolouration.  Worked like a charm.

text:
This recipe was my first attempt at making anything with avocados and I've made this particular one twice already.  I followed the recipe almost as written but left out tomatoes and cilantro because I don't like them.  I used parsley instead and eyeballed the salt amount so it was probably about 1/4 tsp.   I put everything in the blender and it was done in no time. The trick with this is to make it ahead of time and let it sit in the refrigerator at least an hour so the flavors meld. Each time I made it I had none left.  Thanks for a great recipe.

None
text:
Amazing guac recipe, but adjust according to taste.  I prefer a less "sour" taste, so only use half a lime per 3 avocados / per recipe proportions.  Anything more is way too sour in my humble opinion.  Also, I like to go a little lighter on the garlic (too heavy garlic taste for me, which overcrowds the delicate avocado flavor).  I use 1/2 tsp per 3 avocados / recipe proportions.   :)

text:
I would give this 10 stars if I could. I have been making this guacamole for a few years now and I ALWAYS get rave reviews and requests for the recipe. I take no credit and mention I got it here. It is SO delicious that any other guacamole is just sad now. I follow the recipe exactly, except for adding a bit more cilantro because we like it. I "halve" the recipe for just my husband and myself using one large or two small avocados. And I throw it all in a food processor and give it a few whirls. Easy. Yummy. You can stop looking for the perfect recipe - this is it!!

text:
It's a solid recipe but I prefer far more tomato and garlic in my guacamole. I triple the tomato, double or triple the garlic, preferably use 4 large avocados instead of 3, and call it "Mama's Guacamole Salad". It's a big hit with everyone. I've also found you can omit the salt and nobody will notice unless it's the focus of the meal (i.e. a large bowl of dip for chips).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made guacamole for the first time with this recipe and it was a HIT at work. Was even asked for the recipe. I took another reviewer's advice by lightly mashing 2 of the avocados with a fork, and then chopping the last one into small chunks  to stir in. I stored it in a plastic container with a seed and it didn't go brown for hours after serving. Lastly, I didn't have any cayenne pepper so I just used an extra large pinch of paprika instead. Very small alterations, so I still give this recipe a 5 star rating. Will make again for sure!

text:
As usual I can't just make a straight recipe. This was a great base but here's what I did to jazz it up for our tastes. I used 2 avocados. I added a 1 1/2 tbsp of mayo, 1/4 to 1/2 cup salsa (I didn't have tomatoes), 1 tbsp dried cilantro, 1 tsp chipotles powder, and, since I had some crumbled feta cheese I needed to use, I added about 2 tbsp to the mix.  It was delicious!

text:
I've made this dozens of times. I follow the recipe, but would advise adding 1/2 the salt and lime and then doing a taste test before adding it all. Limes of various sizes hold +/- juice. We had one batch that was overpowered by lime. Likewise, avocado size can result in too +/- salt. Too much and you'll be wishing you had 1 extra avocado!

Living in the SW, I am able to get guac many places. Since trying this recipe nothing in a restaurant comes close to this flavor. I make it just as written with an occasional shortcut. I would specify red onions in the recipe and I add about 1 tsp of ground cumin.  I also add 1 finely chopped jalapeno.

Display Name:
mikijensen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a virgin when it comes to homemade guac, but I know good guac when I taste it and this one is gooooold (I'm still in summer Olympics mode)! I didn't change anything about the recipe, although now that I've tried it once, I may experiment a bit with the suggestions of other reviewers. The only thing I did was add one step because I have a husband who is adverse to raw onions in his food (such a little whiner!). I refused to omit this very important ingredient because it adds to the overall flavor and helps give the guac a nice texture.  So I used a trick my mom taught me which is to soak the chopped onions in water for about 20 mins. This helps to decrease the strong onion-y smell and taste. Once the chopped onion has soaked, strain it, dump it out onto a paper towel, ring it dry, and add to the guac mixture. Finally, continue on your merry way with the rest of the recipe and enjoy!

userID:

Display Name:
29bastet

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3795138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You do not need any measurements for this wonderful recipe. Just taste as you go. The key is putting in the tomato toward the end but before the lemon and lime. You do not want to squash your tomatoes. You can either season after you've chopped the onion or after. I do after so I can taste with the onion so I don't over-season. I don't add cilantro as I feel the onion and spices add enough kick but for more spicy, go for it! Also, I do not use regular salt. I use season salt and a little at a time between tastings so make sure I don't overdue it. I feel regular salt adds too much saltiness to the dip.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-07-23T22:59:26.39
helpfulCount:
0

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG!!!! So! I'm almost 37 years old and until the past year I didn't like Guacamole. Something with avocados and the texture. So I recently started liking it and had a craving for it. For someone that doesn't even like guac they much!!! OMG!  When I tasted this I said out loud, "mmmmmmmm!  that's good!" Definitely give this recipe a try. I used red onions instead of white; didn't add cayenne (I don't like hot); and I think I added double what they call for with the cilantro. I am a salt lover, but I feel you don't need to add as much salt as they say. Probably half of that. Or perhaps a dash or to taste. The other reviewers are correct- the lime is key! Gives it a different yummy flavor. I did taste it before adding the garlic, and honestly you could go either way, with or without, and I too am a garlic lover. It tastes great even without garlic. I mashed mine with a mash potato masher :-) and it kept it the perfect consistency.Thanks for an amazing recipe!!

text:
Excellent and easy to make.  I like mine with a little kick so I increased the cayenne a bit, but since that's the only real spicy ingredient this guacamole can be easily adjusted to your own taste.  Don't forget the lime juice - not only does it add a little zing to the flavor, it also helps keep the finished guacamole from turning brown.  Also, always refrigerate any leftovers and it'll be good for a day or so.

text:
I make this guacamole regularly and it's always a hit!  The taste really changes depending on the type of minced garlic I use (freshly minced vs. jarred).  Both ways are really good but freshly minced is better.  But on those lazy days when I don't feel like chopping garlic and use jarred it still turns out fantastic!  I agree with other reviewers who say be careful with the salt.  I used seasoning salt once and I thought it was too salty.

text:
This was really good guac!  I was a little nervous about making it, and I was very pleasantly surprised at how it turned out.  I did make slight modifications - a little less onion (maybe about 3/8 cup yellow onion) for my DH's preference, and only 1/2 tsp salt (I'm trying to cut back a little on salt, a little bit at a time).  I also used grape tomatoes instead of Romas, since that's what I had.  
My husband suggested a little more lime; and I think using red onion (full amount suggested in the recipe) instead of yellow onion would be good, too.
I was looking for a good guacamole recipe, and this is definitely it!  I will definitely be making this again.  Thank you!!

text:
I make this recipe once a month at least. It is my favorite guacamole recipe of all time...restaurant or homemade. I have also used some fresh salsa when out of onion and it was still good, but the recipe as is is perfection. I never use the salt amount in a recipe. My modus operandi is to cut it in half or less. I use a pinch of sea salt or just rely on the salt from tortilla chips. Also, I would not consider myself a big cilantro fan, but I use the whole amount and fresh is a must.

None
text:
I love this version...it is the gold standard in guacamole!  I substitute 1 tsp garlic powder for minced garlic & 3 TBSP Nellie & Joe key lime juice for the lime juice.  I pulse the avocado, lime juice garlic powder using the immersion blender until it is a smooth consistency.  I slice the onion and tomato using mandolin, then chop finely with a knife.  Mix all together & let sit for a couple of hours to allow flavors to meld...good stuff!

Seriously the best guacamole I've ever made or had.  So fresh!   I upped the cilantro because I didn't feel like measuring it and we LOVE cilantro. city:

country:
None
text:
This is a good base recipe for the ingredients that need to go into a good guacamole but the ratios are waaaay off. First of all, I'm not sure how that is only 4 servings. I was making this for a potluck of about 20 people so I tripped the recipe. I ended up with a massive salad bowl almost full. I only needed to bring half to the potluck! And 1 tsp of salt to three avocados? Again, in my tripled recipe I only used 1 tsp so I can't imagine how salty that would be with only three avocados... If you plan to make this, I'd say max 1/2 tsp for the original recipe and it would likely serve at least 10 people. This isn't a meal, it's a snack or an appetizer!

userID:
5597157
Display Name:
Brian McGrew
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
3
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3515183.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With a few alterations to suit our tastes, this is great!  Everyone goes nuts over it!  First I've replaced the minced garlic with garlic powder.  Second, the onion and tomato individually have need replaced with a batch of fresh Pico De Gallo (the local store has some fantastic hand made stuff) and I add in the juice from the Pico as well to re-hydrate the garlic power.  We prefer to make larger (2x or 3x) sized batches of the goods - it does seem the larger the batch the better the flavor...  And, lastly, there is _nothing_ wrong with making it 2 or 3 days in advance!  To store it, pour it into a storage container with a tight lid but, cover the top of your green goo with plastic wrap, right down on top of it and all the way to the edges, getting all the air out.  Lid up and put in the cold box!  We always make it at least a day in advance but more if we have time!

text:
Highly recommended! This was absolutely yummy! This is my first time making guacamole so I scaled the recipe down to 1 avocado so that if I didn't like it, I could just toss it. Now I wish I made double the recipe, it was so good I couldn't stop eating it! Never even made it to the refrigerator. I'll be making a heap of this again and will chill first for an hour as instructed, I'm sure it will taste even better! I did not omit any ingredient but I did lessen the salt a bit and added just a dash of pepper.

I love this recipe & am always asked to bring the guacamole now!  I use the recipe as a guideline for how much of everything I should add but I adjust depending on taste and it always turns out great! 
Take the advice of other reviewers and only add salt to taste!

text:
This guacamole is fantastic. I had two avocados that were ready to use  however I did not have any fresh tomatoes,  limes or cilantro. So I decided to open a can of diced tomatoes and rinsed them real well and used some dried cilantro and some bottled lime juice. All the other ingredients I had on hand. Mixed them all together and let me tell you, it was fantastic. I did refrigerate for one our before using.

text:
This will be my guacamole recipe for many years to come! It has wonderful flavor and it looks beautiful. The first time I made it I got every last drop of juice out of my lime and the guacamole was a bit too lime-y. Now when I make it I tend to go a little easier on the lime juicing(but I still use 1 lime)  and it is perfection!! AND because there is so much lime, it can stay out at a party and keep all its beautiful colors. This is the dreamboat of guacamoles.

text:
I've made guac before, with, usually, poor results, this recipe is, however, fantastic.  Easy to make, simple ingredients, enough acid to keep it from turning brown, just salt enough to add flavor without being overpowering, great cilantro flavor, and just enough tomato go give it some color.   When you store it, put some plastic wrap right on top of the guac to keep the air off.   I add a few(+) dashes of hot sauce when time to serve.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Added 1/2 tsp. Cumin and omitted lime. We like the sting, zip and color of red onion instead of white. Garlic must be minced fresh-no jarred stuffed. We mix it all with the same chef knife used on ingredients and as we "fold" in ingredients with the knife we get the perfect consistency of creamy and chunky...my m.i.l. taught me that trick. Leave pit in the guacamole and press Saran Wrap flat against to completely seal out air that can turn it brown.

text:
My mom went to Philadelphia so I had to make me and my dad dinner. I usually make quesadillas so I wanted something Mexican to go with them. The recipe calls for way to much salt, so I cut it down to half a teaspoon. I would actually recommend no salt at all if the chips you use are very salty, like mine. I also used cherry tomatoes instead of plum tomatoes and a little less garlic. Best guac ever! So much better the Chipotle and Taco Bell.

text:
I had gotten a big bag of ripe avocados on sale and needed to use them up, so I decided to make this recipe for a party. My challenge was that the party was a three hour drive away. So I left the avocados whole and unpeeled, and mixed all the other ingredients with lime juice in a big lidded bowl. When I arrived to the party, I just peeled and pitted all the avocados and mashed and mixed it on the spot. Everyone really enjoyed it, and the veggies were really flavorful from marinating in the citrus juice! Great recipe, nice ingredient proportions!

text:
This was good.  The lime however was overpowering the guac, so I next time I make this I will use 1/2 to 3/4 of the lime juice.  Also, the cayenne needed more kick so I added an additional pinch. I originally left out the salt, but decided it definitely needs some to bring out the fresh garlic flavor so I added 6 turns of my sea salt grinder. I will also add more cilantro next time as we both love cilantro. It's a matter of preference & my fiance was my taste tester & after a few modifications from the original recipe, he agreed this was good.

text:
Good, solid base recipe that is easy to customize to your family's taste. I ended up using about a 1/3rd cup fresh salsa (drained) instead of the tomatoes and part of the onion (mine were bad) and used a bit more cilantro. This recipe really lets the few ingredients shine.  We will have again.

text:
We were going to a guacamole contest party, and I had never made guacamole before.  I used this exact recipe but then added Costco's Mango Salsa into the guacamole (approx. 4 big spoonfuls). Out of 15 guacamole recipes we tied for first.  I did add the cayenne pepper.  It was sweet and delicious.

text:
So yummy!  I didn't really measure anything, but I think I was pretty close to the amounts in the recipe.  It was really delicious, very similar to my favorite restaurant guacamole.  I also didn't mash the guacamole, just cut it into small chunks and mixed it all together, so it got a little mashed up but still had chunks of guacamole.  I will definitely be making this again!

I more or less doubled the recipe, but didn't quite double the onion. I subbed 1 tbsp. of dried cilantro for the 3 tbsp fresh, and 1/4 tsp. dehydrated minced garlic for the 1tsp fresh minced garlic. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic stuff!  I tweaked it a little bit (used a combination of spring and red onions, a bit of Tabasco Chipotle hot sauce, a dash of Maggi seasoning, a pinch of oregano and cumin), but the basic recipe is fabulous!

I moved to Australia 3 years ago, and love the 'cuisine', if I may call it that:  a mixture of South Asian, Indonesian, Indian and bush tucker, very fresh, with lots of chillies!  This fits right in, as it can be tweaked and turned to Mexican, Thai, whatever.  Wonderfully flexible!

As far as cost goes:  I got 3 overripe avocados on special for 2 AUD today ($1.80 US?) and the cilantro probably cost 0.70 AUD (60c US?), so the dip costs about what a jar of pre-prepared guacamole does in the super, but it's much better!  :-)

Thank you!!!

text:
I added this recipe to my "Recipe Box" in February, 2012 in the event my jars of premixed Guacamole Spice I carried to Costa Rica became non-usable. Despite being seal, the humidity here was just too much.  This recipe was a tremendous suprise!  It was as good, perhaps better than those jars of premixed stuff.  The only chages i made was using Costa Rica's "Cayote Cilantro" and removing the core and seeds from the Roma Tomatoes before dicing. I will never buy that other stuff again!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my second time making the recipe. I usually use half of a lemon - because I use organic and the flavor is extra intense, as compared to regular store-bought lemons. I had seen a variety of reviews from others stating that they had used cumin. I didn't have cumin on its own, but I did have a curry blend that primarily contained cumin. The added middle-eastern flare definitely improved the flavor. I believe this recipe is highly flexible. Don't be afraid to experiment!

text:
We really like this recipe.  It's quick and easy to make.  I've made it with and without garlic or cilantro (ran out), yellow onions and red onions.  The amount of salt and lime is just fine as well.  If I want the guacamole more thick, I seed the tomatoes.  If I want it a little more thin, I keep the seeds.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe makes the finest guacamole ever!  When I served this at a recent potluck, it was gone before the event even started, people just couldn't stop eating it.  I did cut back on the salt (personal preference) but the rest of the recipe is spot-on perfect.  The kicker of the recipe is the cilantro, I may add a Tbsp more the next time I make it.  A definite keeper recipe!
Added: I have been making this recipe for two years now and have found that a tsp of cumin and 1/2-1 tsp of smoked coriander seed takes this over the top!  And yes, the added cilantro is amazing.  Simple a great recipe and very adaptable.  This is the recipe I will use for many years to come!

text:
I have this saved in my favorites. It's the only recipe for guacamole that I and my 4yo absolutely love. Even my husband, who doesn't care for guacamole will sneak a few chips. I add about half the amount of salt though and substitute the lime for a lemon. Put all but tomatoes in the stand mixer and blend with a lid slowly. Fold tomatoes in as you place it in the serving container. Best ever!

First time making this recipe and already making alterations, lol. I like the chunk and it definitely works better with ripe Haas avocados. I added green pepper, ground pepper, used 1/2 of a lemon instead of lime for 2 avocados, Frank's red hot sauce and 1/2 a jalapeo minced (We love spice!) and it was pretty good. Placed it on top of a warm tostada spread with Pace's Jalapeo and Pepper Jack dip, some grilled chicken mixed with black beans and topped with mexican cheese blend, and Ta Da, one heck of a meal.

clearady

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best guacamole of all time!  I made a few adjustments according to my taste.  First, I just about pureed my half onion in a blender (would work in a food processor too).  I don't like the texture of raw onion, and this prevented any tears from being shed.  I just wanted that fresh flavor.

I put in a little extra garlic, a little extra lime juice, and one extra tomato -- just the way I like it.  I also mashed only half of the avocados and cubed the other half to have a chunky (more avocado-y tasting) consistency.  Five stars like this!  

You may need an extra avocado if yours are on the puny side or have plenty of dark spots (better to buy four).  Left out cayenne pepper and cilantro.  Threw in one jalapeno, diced, and seeded for extra zing.  Perfect.

5

text:
This recipe was very good. I halfed the ingredients as I was cooking only for two and did not want to over make the guacamole as it tends to turn brown when it sits for too long. To add a little extra zing, I added a jalapeno pepper (chopped) and I added some cumin. I also added a little extra cilantro. I did not find this recipe too salty as others did. I shall make this again in the future.

country:
None
text:
This is a good, basic recipe for guacamole.  I agree you have to adjust the cilantro and lime to your taste.  I didn't think the tsp of salt was too much at all and I really think that has to do with the avocados as well.  Some just need that little extra salt to bring out the flavor and some don't.  I added a little more than a "pinch" of cayenne because it's one of my favorites and it adds the perfect kick to just about anything.  I feel this needs to set for at least 3 hours though to really get the flavors to meld.  I will definitely make this again.  Thanks for sharing!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Lime, cilantro, and salt are absolute essentials to perfect guacamole, and this recipe incorporates them generously.  Delicious!  This will be my go-to guacamole recipe from now on.  I did notice that the tomatoes softened to unfavorable texture after being stored in the refrigerator for over 24 hours.  I would recommend omitting the tomatoes if you expect to store leftovers.

This was a big hit! Everyone loved the freshness. I let it sit in the fridge for 5-6 hours. This is ,for me, hands down the BEST guacamole recipe!  I have made it several times.  Since finding this recipe I have always make guacamole from scratch.  I recently made it for a party and people just raved about it.    I usually use 2-3 cloves of garlic and leave out the onions (have an onion hater in the house). userID:

Display Name:
Gunner

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love it!!! Added a touch of mint, which is not so important. What is VERY importantly, in my opinion, is squishing all the ingredients together with your two hands. Messy and sloppy, yes, but so wonderful at the same time. Avocado pulp is sensitive and so are tomatoes so they need to be squished just right, to release all the flavors and getting the creamy in wonderful merriment with the chunky. I also minced the garlic inside the lemon juice with the cilantro and mint. Great way to release the flavors. Thank you Mr. Cody!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
We have just recently become fans of Guacamole (as long as its fresh!) and I have never attempted to make it - this was so easy and so good!  I followed it exactly as the recipe stated and only added in about 1/2 t. of Cumin as others had suggested.  I mashed the first 2 avocados and cut up the third in small chunks as we don't like it completely creamy.  My 12 year old loved it and ate the leftovers (there was not much!) the next day.  I also did as others suggested and kept the pit in the container with the leftovers really did help - it had hardly changed color at all.

I love this guacamole! Definitely tasty and doesn't keep me in the kitchen too long, especially when chips and guacamole are my dinner for that night!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My wife and I LOVE guacamole and this recipe is perfect!  The recipe is great as is or you can adjust the ingredients depending on your taste.  We use a little less salt, a little more garlic, a little more cilantro and add some diced jalapeno pepper.  I also typically add lime juice to taste.  Sometimes one lime is too much and sometimes not enough, depending on the size and juiciness of the lime.   FYI - a pastry mixer works great for chunking up the avocado.  Overall this recipe is AMAZING.  If you like guacamole, try this, you won't be disappointed!!!

939278
Display Name:
JENNIFERLYNN2
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is awesome! (Lunch, mmmmmmm) I have made this recipe twice.  I made it the first time with red onions and the second time with green.  I prefer the green onions.  I was going to reduce the cilantro, but after tasting it, I decided to add the full amount.  Also, the first time I made it, 1 tsp. of salt was perfect.  The second time I made it, the avocados were a little smaller and so were the tomatoes, so the batch ended up a little salty.  Next time, I would start with 3/4 tsp, and add more if necessary.  I would also recommend squeezing the juice out of the tomatoes.  When I did not do that the first time, the batch turned out a little runny.  If you like more of a chunky guac. try mashing 2 1/2 of the avocados and then cut up the remaining half.

text:
This is absolutely as good as guacamole can get! Thank you for sharing it!!  Tips: Obviously, you want ripe avacados. Make sure to use the lime juice, NOT lemon. Also, the chill time, although not required, makes it that much better! Also, the serving size is correct, I need at least 2 batches of this stuff if there's any more than a few people eating it. Truly, can't say enough good things about this recipe! :)

text:
I was craving Guacamole from a local restaurant and decided to make it myself. I just happened to have everything needed for this recipe. OMG, it was soooo good.   The one thing I did do, is scrape out the seeds out of the tomatos so they wouldn't be so watery.  I processed 1 of the tomatoes (used 3 roma total) along with the cilantro, onion, garlic and a big scoop of avocado in my mini food processor and then mashed/mixed it in with the remaining avocado.  I gave some to my neighbor who has now asked me to make it again for her. This is a definate keeper.

text:
Very easy to make and came together quickly. Be sure to use very ripe avacadoes - they should be just soft to the touch, or you will not be able to mash them. I used the juice of two limes for this, and opted for red onion instead of white. The family didn't like it, but they don't like guacamole in general, so I can't fault the recipe. I know you will enjoy it - just play with the seasonings and make it your own. When avocadoes are on sale, it is a very economical recipe.

text:
this was AWESOME!!! I thought it even tasted better than the guac i've had at a lot of mexican restaurants. i make this whenever I am making quesadillas for dinner and it is a huge hit. The only thing I feel is that it does not need 2 roma tomatoes - 1 is always enough for me. I feel like the tomato flavor overpowers the avacado and also will make it more watery, which I don't like. I like it to be more of a paste. I also just used garlic powder, and i thought it was wonderful.  I also used red onions and thought they added more to the flavor as well. This will be my go-to recipe for years to come.  Thank you!!!

text:
I love guacamole but had never made it before because I thought it would be really time consuming.  This recipe took under 10 minutes to make and was delicious!  Just make sure your avocados are ripe, and increase the spices to your taste if you like it spicy.  I added half the lime juice and tasted it before adding the rest (based on the other reviews) but I thought it tasted great with the juice from the whole lime.  Thank you for this outstanding and easy recipe!

We LOVE this guacamole!  It's better than our favorite at the local Mexican restaurant. I had 5 avacados, so adapted the recipe. There's only 2 of us now that all the kids are gone, so my husband took leftovers to work and had lots of requests for the recipe.

I think the basics in this recipe are good, but when I made it I tasted way too much salt. I miss my grandfather's garden-grown tomatoes :(

This was my first time making guacamole.  I always thought it was too difficult to make.  Boy, was I wrong!!  This was delicious!  I ate 1/2 of it myself in one sitting!!  The only thing I will do differently next time is cut the salt in half, to 1/2 tsp.  I thought 1 tsp. was too salty.  I used red onion and only used what I thought "looked" like enough.  In addition to minced garlic, I also sprinkled some granulated garlic in it.  This is excellent!  I'm going to make it for my daughter's birthday party next week!

Yum!!  This is by far the best version of guacamole I have ever tasted, and it is very simple to make.  I make it smooth with a food processor before adding the onions and tomatoes.  I live in an area where fresh herbs are costly and hard to come by, and I found using a gelled version of cilantro from McCormick produces much better results than dried.

text:
FABULOUS recipe!  I did make a few changes, mostly because I didn't have quite the exact ingredients...Instead of lime, I used 1 T. of lemon juice; instead of 1 t. of salt, I used only 1/2 t., I used 1 t. onion powder, replaced fresh cilantro with 2 t. dried parsley, used hothouse tomatoes (1 lg., but next time I will use 1 1/2 or 2 because I love tomatoes in mine), and used 1 clove garlic.  It was FABULOUS FABULOUS FABULOUS--even my 3 year old loved it!!!  It never did make it to the fridge.... :)  Thank you for a definite KEEPER!!!

Holy cow this is awesome! I made a few changes to the original though. I left out the lime, garlic, and cilantro just because I didn't have any and added one big heaping spoonful of Mrs. Renfro's picante sauce mixed with a little Pace Picante Sauce and a little ketchup. It was just the right combination of sauces to add to it to make it truly incredible... the BEST guac you will EVER sink your teeth into! Thanks Bob! This guacamole is HEAVEN!
